title: interview-borders-book-festival-prepares-go-online
story: CELEBRITY guests have been a staple of the Borders Book Festival since its launch in .Clearly, festival founder Alistair Moffat has no shortage of impressive contacts to draw upon.Yet some readers might be surprised to learn the identities of the pair he would most like to see in Melrose.ldquoAnt and Dec, blurts Moffat, , without a momentrsquos hesitation.Describing the Geordie duo as ldquogreat guys, he says: ldquoIrsquove been trying to persuade them and they know Irsquoll never give up ndash and theyrsquoll crumble one day.This year, though, there will not be a famous face in sight within the walled gardens of Harmony House.With coronavirus restrictions putting paid to any chance of a physical gathering, the showcase ndash which was originally planned for this weekend ndash is set to take a virtual form.Beginning on July , authors will star in events available for streaming from the festival website.Moffat is still in the middle of booking guests, but he has already snapped up some well-known figures, as ever.ldquoIn a way, itrsquos easier for people, he says, ldquobecause all they have to do is sit in front of their laptop camera ndash they donrsquot have to come to Melrose.Itrsquos now looking more likely than not that Moffat and his fellow directors will triumph over the obstacles posed by COVID-.But back in March, when the virus began to take hold in Britain, a sense of despondency hung over the group.ldquoWe were absolutely heartbroken, because virtually all of our work had been done by then, says Moffat.As it became clearer that a physical event would not be possible, Moffat and his colleagues realigned their ambitions and channelled their energies into simply making sure that the festival would survive.To Moffatrsquos relief, the idea of an online version found favour with sponsors and the Friends of the Festival.ldquoOnly three people wanted their money back and whatrsquos amazing is we had a tsunami of supportive emails from the public, says Moffat, calling the response ldquovery moving.Everyone will be able to watch the streamed events without paying a penny, says Moffat, with viewers merely invited to make a donationthey can afford it.ldquoSome festivals have charged for these things, but we donrsquot think thatrsquos right, says Kelso-born Moffat, himself an author of more than  books.ldquoWersquoll invite people to donatethey wish, but these are hard times ndash people need to put food on the table.Notwithstanding his delight at being able to run the festival this year, despite the dficult conditions, Moffat is already looking forward to theof a physical format.ldquoTherersquos nothing like being in the same place as Melvyn Bragg or Joanna Lumley or Gordon Brown and being able to ask them questions, says Moffat.,params: .pushThe appeal of the Borders Book Festival, according to its founder, lies in the eventrsquos ldquosociability.ldquoThe famous people are not all herded off into a sealed container ndash theyrsquore there to talk to you, says Moffat.ldquoPeople who are extremely well-known, that all peels away and wersquoll see them standing chatting.Which brings us neatly to comedy twosome Ant and Dec, the showbiz stars whose presence Moffat so dearly craves.ldquoWhat people would see from Ant and Dec is just something completely dferent, he says, admiringly, having known the TV personalities for many years.The pair have a book coming out this year, according to Moffat ndash so perhaps his dream might yet come true.Full details of the virtual events, set to run for  weeks, will be published at: www.bordersbookfestival.org

title: black-lives-matter-yorkshire-tea-pg-tips-went-viral
story: The UKs largest tea brands have gone viral online after responding to Twitter users who spoke out against Black Lives Matter.The Black Lives Matter movement has been gaining traction in the UK following protests in America.This is everything you need to know about what happened.What did Yorkshire Tea say As momentum around the Black Lives Matter movement continues to grow, ious brands have been voicing their support.Until now, popular tea brand Yorkshire Tea has remained quiet on the matter.A far-rightvlogger wrote on Twitter: ldquoIrsquom dead chuffed that Yorkshire Tea hasnrsquot supported BLM with a smiling face emoji.The tweet quickly gained the attention of Yorkshire Tea, who wrote back: ldquoPlease donrsquot buy our tea again."Wersquore taking some time to educate ourselves and plan proper action before we post. We stand against racism. #BlackLivesMatter.The reply from Yorkshire Tea has gained more than K likes on Twitter, and .K retweets as well.After the response from Yorkshire Tea, the vloggerchanged her Twitter profile to acknowledge the exchange, writing that she was ldquodisavowed by Yorkshire Tea.How did PG Tips get involved In response to the exchange, some Twitter users said they would be switching their tea allegiance to rival brand PG Tips -but it didnrsquot take long before thatcompany claried its own stance on the Black Lives Matter Movement.In response to Yorkshire Tea, one user named Pamela wrote in a now deleted tweet: ldquoSo now Irsquove got to buy PG Tips   Well f me. This sucks. And Yorkshire Tea is done. Good luck with the bs stance.PG Tips quickly responded with: ldquoYeah it does suck, Pamela. If you are boycotting teas that stand against racism, yoursquore going to have to find two new tea brands now. #BlackLivesMatter #Solidaritea.What is #Solidaritea The hashtag on Twitter is now full of users praising the brands for their response and enjoying cups of tea.One user wrote: ldquoAbsolutely delighted that the choice of tea in our household angers racists #BlackLivesMatterUK #SolidariteaAnother tweeted: ldquo@YorkshireTea and @PGTips yoursquove made my day #solidaritea with a screenshot of the exchange between the two brands.Another took the time to showcase what the backlash against the companies reveals about some people in the UK.They wrote: ldquoSo people are choosing to boycott tea companies such as @PGTips and @YorkshireTea because they are against racism  Absolutely pathetic. And then they say the UK isnrsquot a racist country. Yeah, okay, keep telling yourself that #solidaritea.Have other tea brands got involved with #Solidaritea Another tea brand, Tea Pigs, replied to PG Tipsrsquo and Yorkshire Tearsquos tweet with: ldquoNicely done guys. Make that three #solidaritea.There havebeen calls from users to have other brands speak out on the matter as well.ldquoWaiting for Tetley and Twinings to enter the group chathellip #solidaritea, wrote one user.Another tweeted: ldquoHas anyone heard from Twinings  Pukka  Scottish Blend  #solidaritea.ldquoWell @TwiningsUK, are you going to stand against the racists or with them  #solidaritea #BlackLivesMatter #Twinings, tweeted another user.

title: ant-dec-apologise-using-blackface-saturday-night-takeaway

title: borders-festival-blackening-faces-cannot-go
story: FESTIVAL organisers in Peebles say they will not tolerate participants ldquoblackening their faces.The Beltanecommittee published a statement on June  after social media users expressed disappointment that some revellers had worn ldquoethnic makeup over the years.Beltane organisers said in their statement: ldquoWe can confirm that the committee has not and will never condone or tolerate anyone taking part in our fancy dress competition and parade who has blackened their face.In the statement, the committee says it has recently been asked to review ldquocultural appropriation and ldquoblackening of faces, adding that it is seeking help from a lawyer to make sure its guidance on equality matters is appropriate.However, the statement says there are some changes which ldquocannot happen overnight.In an attempt to offer clarication, the committeersquos secretary George Blair told this newspaper: "These are committee decisions. Our committee cant operate over Zoom as some are not tech-savvy.He added: "If we were to withdraw  costumes, wed have to replace them with something dferent."Some of the issues raised are valid and were going to change these things."The committee says it did not receive a complaint before its recent annual general meeting, going on to express disappointment that any concerns were not put forward directly.Looking to the future, Mr Blair, , encourages people to contact the committee with any complaints, including those around racism and racist behaviour.He said: "We want everyone to be on the same side."Peebles is a predominantly white town, but anyone of any creed or colour can join us."Wed love to see more people."Changes to costuming at the festival were made in  when complaints were lodged over the Nursery Rhymes Come to Le dress-up theme where golliwog costumes were worn ndash and subsequently banned.Recently, an online petition has been circulated asking the committee to make further changes to its costume guidelines. title: find-winner-walter-scott-prize-2020
story: THE winner of the Walter Scott Prize for Historical Fiction will be announced tomorrow .A ceremony had originally been scheduled to take place at the Borders Book Festival.But the festival was cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions, so the winner will be declared on BBC Radio  instead.To hear the announcement, you can tune in to the channels Front Row programme at .pm.The organisers of the competition hope a formal ceremony can be held at Abbotsford later in the year.The shortlist was revealed in March.Previous winners include Hilary Mantel, Andrea Levy, Sebastian Barry, Tan Twan Eng, Robert Harris, John Spurling, Simon Mawer, Benjamin Myers and Robin Robertson.This is the shortlist for the prizeThe Narrow Land by Christine Dwyer HickeyThe Parisian by Isabella HammadTo Calais, In Ordinary Time by James MeekShadowplay by Joseph OrsquoConnorThe Redeemed by Tim PearsA Sin of Omission by Marguerite Poland

title: coronavirus-almost-13-000-workers-borders-furloughed
story: ALMOST , workers in the Borders have been furloughed since the start of the coronavirus pandemic.The Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme was launched back in April.And of the , workers in the region, a total of , are having  per cent of their wages paid by the government.John Lamont, MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, said: "This historic intervention by the Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, has ensured that thousands of people still have a job toto, despite the problems caused by coronavirus. It is reassuring that so many businesses and employees have been able to make use of this scheme."The UK Government is doing whatever it takes to get the Scottish Borders, Scotland and the whole country through this crisis. I am grateful to the hard work of civil servants and ministers for putting these packages in place so quickly."Nevertheless, I am very aware of the economic hit that will come from the pandemic."Unfortunately, we have already seen some indication from Borders businesses that there will be challenging times ahead."The scheme was also praised by secretary of state for Scotland, Alister Jack.He added: ldquoSo far, nearly , jobs across Scotland have been saved by direct UK Government coronavirus support. Through the job retention scheme , Scottish jobs have been furloughed, and the UK Government has spent pound million on supporting , self-employed people in ScotlandldquoIn the South of Scotland alone that amounts to more than , jobs saved. Rural communities such as ours face particular challenges and Irsquom very pleased that the UK Government has been able to step in."

title: no-redundancies-furlough-insists-stobo-castle
story: THE chairman of Stobo Castle insists staff will not be made redundant while the furlough scheme is in place.Stephen Winyard gave  workers his assurances this week.It comes after the Crieff Hydro and Macdonald hotel groups announced jobs are at risk in Peebles and Cardrona respectively.Mr Winyard said: ldquoWe were all hugely saddened to hear the devastating news of , redundancies at Macdonald Hotels and a further  within the Crieff Hydro Group that will respectively lead to signicant job losses at the nearby Cardrona Macdonald Hotel and Peebles Hydro."To address any understandable concerns, we have given a categorical assurance to our  strong workforce that no redundancies will take place before the end of the furlough scheme on October ."In a statement, Mr Winyard also called on the Scottish Government to relax social distancing rules, to help businesses in the hospitality industry.He added: "We have secured funding through the governmentrsquos Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme to finance the incremental contribution that all employers are required to make from August  to the cost of the Job Retention Scheme."However the hospitality industry will undoubtedly require further state support to ensure its survival through the long winter months."In their update on June , I am calling for the Scottish Government to halve social distancing from July ."This will allow the hospitality industry to prepare for re-opening on July  at a capacity that is financially viable."This, of course, is subject to the R rate continuing to fall and there is no indication of a second wave of the virus."The Job Retention Scheme was created to enable businesses to preserve their loyal and dedicated workforces for when they re-open and that is exactly what we plan to do."The welfare of the Stobo team is our top priority and we do hope that other businesses in the hospitality sector will follow suit, thereby sustaining the tourism industry that is so vital to the economy of the Scottish Borders."

title: can-take-recycling-centres-borders
story: MORE types of waste can now be taken to Borders tips.As previously reported, recycling centres are now open to the public.And this week, Scottish Borders Council has said that some large items will now be accepted.They include mattresses, plastic garden furniture, kitchen units, carpet, wood and wooden furniture.However, residents are still unable to take household electrical appliances, such as fridges, TVs and microwaves and metal objects.Cardboard is also not being accepted and should be flat packed and put alongside kerbside recycling bins for collection.A maximum of five bin bags of waste are allowed per visit, including a limit of two large general waste or wood items.Scottish Borders Councilrsquos chief executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoThank you to members of the public who have attended our recycling centres and complied with the temporary restrictions so far, which has allowed us to now accept more waste types.ldquoThe restrictions will continue to be reviewed and adjusted as we move forward, with any changes communicated in advance.ldquoWe would continue to ask anyone using a community recycling centre to follow the restrictions and guidance we have in place, and treat our staff with respect.The full list of restrictions can be viewed by clicking here.

title: football-memorabilia-items-worth-fortune
story: FOOTBALL fans have been urged to check their lofts as they could be sitting on a small fortune.From classic replica shirts to sticker albums, many could be sitting ona miniaturegoldmine without even knowing it.If you manage to get your hands on the right item at the right time, you could secure a tidy profit.Do you know what to look for and how much an item you already own in storage could be worth Research has identied exactly which football-related keepsakes have the most value in .Herersquos a snapshot of some ofthe most popular football memorabilia.A David Beckham Manchester United home shirt from their treble-winning  season is worth pound..The - season Liverpool home shirt fetches pound online, and the Arsenal - away shirt can be worth pound.The prices of other rare items, including medals, sticker albums and programmes, have also shot up and they can sell for hundreds.The complete Panini France rsquo World Cup sticker album is now worth pound.If you are lucky enough to own any of these items, then congratulations - you could sell for a nice profit. Alternatively, keeping it may well provide sentimental value. Either way, itrsquos a win-win.If you have something you think is of value, or thinking of buying a collectable, these are the main things to look out for.Age:anything more than  years old is most collectable. Whatrsquos in your grandadrsquos shed Rarity:there are many available, this will bring the value down. Not everyonersquos been to an FA Cup Final ... anything final-related holds a lot of value. Cup final programmes are always of a high value.Popularity:programmes with an iconic footballer on the cover or detailing a famous match are the most prized and valuable. A footballerrsquos or managerrsquos last game for a club increases the match day programmersquos value - so itrsquos worth checking.Condition:it goes without saying that creases, missing staples and water damage all harm the price of the memorabilia.With the Premier League season back on, now could be a great time to dust off any memorabilia yoursquove had for the past few decades.

title: walter-scott-prize-2020-success-christine-dwyer-hickey
story: IRISH author Christine Dwyer Hickey has won pound, after claiming the Walter Scott Prize for Historical Fiction .Judges considered her novel The Narrow Landto be a ldquomasterpiece for its portrayal of Edward and Jo Hopperrsquos marriage.In a video acceptance speech, Ms Hickey said: ldquoI really, really appreciate this recognition.The winner was originally going to be announced at the Borders Book Festival in Melrose, but coronavirus restrictions forced a change of plan.Ms Hickeyrsquos book about the marriage of two American artists led to her triumphing over fellow authors Joseph OrsquoConnor, Isabella Hammad, James Meek, Tim Pears and Marguerite Poland.Ms Hickey said: ldquoWriting a novel takes a big chunk of onersquos le - The Narrow Landwas six years in the making - which is why I really, really appreciate this recognition.ldquoI would like to send my thoughts to a grave in a hillside cemetery in Nyack, overlooking the Hudson river, a few miles from New York City, where the artists Edward and Jo Hopper lie, and where I hope they have at last found peace.ldquoI also hope they will forgive me the intrusion.The judging  consisted of Elizabeth Buccleuch, James Holloway, Elizabeth Laird, Jim Naughtie, Kirsty Wark and chairwoman Katie Grant.Their joint statement reads: ldquoItrsquos a risky business, portraying the marriage of two artists, particularly when both the marriage and the art have already been picked over by biographers and art historians.ldquoChristine Dwyer Hickey has embraced the risk and created a masterpiece.ldquoIn The Narrow Land, she reaches into the guts of the marriage of Jo and Edward Hopper and into the heart of the creative impulse itself. And more, much more.ldquoQuietly, inexorably, and with pinpoint perception, our winner has brought to dramatic le not just the Hoppersrsquo intimate eruptions but the tensions and complexities in those around them, from two young boys scarred by war to the transient summer crowd at Cape Cod, and though this forensic lens we glimpse the upheavals that were to shake all Americans in the post-war world.ldquoWith the pull of a shting sea, The Narrow Landdrew the judges back again and again, each reading richer than the one before.The Walter Scott Prize, founded in , rewards the best fiction set  years ago or more. It is open to authors from the UK, Ireland and the Commonwealth.This years prize-winner was announced on BBC Radio  at .pm on June .

title: racism-borders-sisters-tell-story
story: GROWING up as mixed-race girls in the Borders was often a struggle, according to sisters Sara and Hannah Alkashmim.Faeces smeared on their door handles. Gravy-filled condoms thrown at their doorstep. Windows smashed and tyres slashed.These are examples of the racist attacks that the Alkashmim family say they have endured over the last three decades, with some episodes leading to court cases.As the daughters of a white mother and an Arabian father from Yemen, Sara and Hannah stood out when they attended Peebles Priorsford Primary School and, later, the towns high school.Now living and working in Edinburgh as nursery teachers, the pair feel confident to share the horrors they faced during their childhood ndash in the hope of changing attitudes in the region.The abuse started early for -year-old Sara and Hannah, , who can remember being called racial slurs in primary school.They continued to be targeted throughout their teenage years, they say.Former Beltane Queen Sara recalls being assaulted in Galashiels when walking to the bus station after college.She said: "Three girls, who I had already reported to the police, attacked me behind the bus station."They kicked and hit me, called me names which included racial slurs, and stole my phone."And when Hannah was  or , she says, she was whipped on the back of the leg with a metal dog lead, resulting in heavy bruising needing medical attention.Hannah said: "It was the build-up of years of racial comments, of being sent memes of women in burqas, of casual racist chanting directed towards me, and I just had enough. I had to go to the police."Although racism was not their only reason for moving away, Sara says they wanted a ldquofresh start."I never planned on staying, but I did feel like I couldnt stay there anymore because of the racism, said Sara.The sisters believe the best way to tackle some of the racist attitudes in Peebles, whether intentional or unintentional, is through education.Sara said: "Racism is throughout Scotland but I think it can be worse in rural areas."We didnt learn anything in school about racism, black history or dferent cultures."If people were able to call us names as early as primary two or three, then these issues need to be addressed in the curriculum as early as that, too."Hannah added: "We dont want to just share our stories and thats it.ldquoThere needs to be positive change and the best way to do that is through education.Sara and Hannah attended the Black Lives Matter protest in Edinburgh last Sunday , where they obeyed social distancing rules while wearing masks and gloves.The global movement has inspired the sisters to voice their own struggles on social media.,params: .pushNow self-isolating for two weeks following the protest, Hannah said: "Its the first time that people are really listening.ldquoA lot of people dont want to talk about racism, its uncomfortable, but were finally starting to have these conversations."Its given me the confidence that were not going to get shut down. People do care, and they want to help."However, we have had a bit of backlash from some people from Peebles who feel like were putting the town down."But we cant deny what happened to us. We cant be dishonest and say it was only a few people, because it wasnt."Were not saying that everyone in Peebles is racist and its not always intentional."Sara added: "I still think theres lots of people who disagree and think there isnt actually any racism in Peebles."Its important to make it clear racism still happens across Scotland, including in Peebles currently."We love the town. Its a beautul place but there is definitely room for improvement when it comes to tackling racism."

title: scotlands-lockdown-easing-scottish-spca-advice-dog-owners-know
story: DOG owners are being urged to start preparing for the easing of lockdown in Scotland ndash with our furry friends facing separation anxiety after months of extra human contact.Before tighter measures were introduced, most dogs were likely suited to the routine of their owners ndash which included being left indoors while they went out for work.But since March, thousands more people in Scotland have been working from home.The immediate impact would, of course, prove to be popular with your four-legged friend ndash however animal experts are warning of the consequences once lockdown ends.Speaking to Radio Clyde News, Alan Grant from the Scottish SPCA said there will likely be ldquoteething problems for dogs as measures ease further and office working s.He told the radio station: ldquoDogs are much like us, any change to the routine or their day-to-day le is going to have an impact on them.ldquoWersquove all had to change and work from home and adapt our working protocols, which has been dficult for us at the beginning but wersquore now more used to it. Itrsquos the same for the dogs.ldquoDogs may have been a bit unsettled at the beginning with the owners being there but theyrsquove now adapted to that situation ndash and itrsquos now about adapting to going back to the old situation of the owner not being there, and thatrsquos where there will be a bit of teething problems for a lot of people at the beginning.So what can I do The Scottish SPCA have urged owners to start with "micro" changes now- leaving their dogsfor a short period of time with something to keep them occupied.They also suggest investing in a camera to have a greater understanding of your dogs behaviour when you are not there.Mr Grant continued: "We want to start right now with very small changes, we call it stress inoculation. If we never leave our dogs, theyrsquore never going to get used to it."So we would leave them for micro amounts of time ndash but wersquod do a lot of stuff before we went to leaving them."Wersquod look at their day-to-day le and how can we make that le more enriching."Are they food motivated  If so, can we give them something that will take them five or ten minutes to eat, while we leave for five or ten minutes ndash then see how they are."Something  that is a great idea is to get a camera and see how your dog is actually behaving when you go out."That way yoursquoll know whether they go sleep for half an hour and then get up and start panting or is it immediately when we leave."They seem to cope well Mr Grant told the radio stationit is "imporant" to know how your dog reacts to being left on its own.He continued: "If they are confident being left on their own for a short while, then we probably donrsquot need to deal with separation anxiety because they can cope being left.,params: .push"If that is the case, we just need to build up on that time that they are on their own."Something like getting a camera can be very much to your advantage so we know what we are dealing with ndash perhaps revealing that they can cope fine but just get bored, so we can enrich their le and give them other things to do so that they are not as bored when you go out."What they struggle This likely means your dog suffers from seperation anxiety.Symptoms of this includeyour dog starts pacing and panting the moment you leave the door.In that case, Mr Grant says, you "would maybe need to look at some form of tailored programme for your particular dogthat is the case ndash but without knowing that itrsquos very hard to make that call."You can find our more information from the Scottish SPCA here.

title: scotlands-schools-lockdown-five-key-updates-nicola-sturgeons-announcement
story: THE First Minister has today tried to address the concerns from ldquoanxious parents and students about the impact of coronavirus on schooling.Speaking about plans for Scottish youngsters toto school from August , Nicola Sturgeon said there should be ldquono doubt about the priority the government is giving education ndash to ldquomake sure young people do not lose out on education or have their le chances damaged.It comes as no new coronavirus deaths were reported in Scotland in the last  hours ndash the third time the figure has remained the same since lockdown began.A total of  patients have died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, no change on Sundayrsquos figure.The death total previously remained the same on June  and June  -but the First Minister stressed that deaths are lower at weekends.What did the First Minister say about education . lsquoMaximisersquo in-school learningMs Sturgeon says ministers expectcouncils to put in place arrangements that ldquoabsolutely maximise the amount of time youngsters spend in school.The majority of pupils from Scotland have not been in the classroom since March.ldquoThe Scottish Government will be scrutinising council plans very closely, Ms Sturgeon said.ldquoWhere we conclude all possible steps have not been taken to maximise face to face teaching and learning, we will ask councils to reconsider and revise their plans.ldquoWhere there are genuine issues of resources the Scottish Government will work with councils to address those..lsquoBlendedrsquo learning for less than a yearThe First Minister said she wants blended learning - where kids have a mix of in-school and at-home education - to be no longer needed by the end of the next academic year.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoOur aim will be toto normal schooling as quickly as we possibly can, recognising that along the way we must build the confidence of parents, young people and teachers that schools are safe.ldquoIt is absolutely not the case that we are planning for blended learning, with children learning at home for part of the school week, to last a year or anything like it.ldquoOn the contrary, we do not want blended learning to last a single second longer than is absolutely necessary, so we will be working with councils toschools to normal as quickly as we can.ldquoWe want young people to be back having face-to-face teaching for % of the school week as soon as it is feasible.. Next yearrsquos exams The First Minister made clear it was the Governmentrsquos ldquoclear intention that exams will go ahead in in .This comes after comments from Education Secretary John Swinney, who revealed local authorities are being given guidance to gather evidence of grades in case exams cannot go ahead.,params: .push. Holidays cancelled or weekend schooling After being questioned by journalists on the issue, the First Minister said the Scottish Government would not rule out cancelling further school holidays, including the October break, to allow pupils to maximise time in class.Likewise, Ms Sturgeon added they also will not rule out opening schools on a Saturdaythere is evidence it will help.ICYMI - todayrsquos @scotgovdaily update focused on school education and the importance of getting it back to normal as quickly as we safely can. https:t.co cnzkwVbmdash Nicola SturgeonJune , . Regular reviewsThe Scottish Governmentrsquos regular three-weekly reviews of coronvirus restrictions will now include specic consideration of the evidence and data relating to transmission of the virus within schools and young people, she added.She pledged: ldquoWhere that suggests that safety and restrictions can belted or eased without putting pupils and teachers at undue risk we will do so.The Scottish Governmentrsquos International Council of Education Advisers will also consider the experience in out countries, Ms Sturgeon added.Nicola Sturgeon went on to state the Scottish Government would be working with councils to ensure ldquoenhanced support is available ldquofor any time that young people do spend learning at home.

title: douglas-crawfords-message-melrose-festival-fans
story: THIS week should have seen Melrose mark its annual festival.However, the event is among the many postponed due to coronavirus restrictions.Melrosian-elect Douglas Crawford and festival chairman Rob Moffat have issued a video message on Facebook.Douglas said: "Obviously its very sad that were unable to celebrate the festival this week, but I hope youre managing to stay safe and well during title: virtual-beltane-festival-begins-peebles
story: A VIRTUAL Beltane Festival is under way in Peebles.The physical event was cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions.But residents are nevertheless being urged to take part in a range of activities this week.In a video message posted on Facebook, festival chairman Paul Spence said: "We still wanted to ensure we marked the occasion in the best way that we can."Mr Spence called on residents to "turn the town red and white".He said: "Lets get the bunting up, lets celebrate our great festival and,you want, include some previous house decorations."He also invited people to update their social media profiles with red-and-white images and pictures of previous festivals."Lets get as many great memories on social media as possible," he said.More information on events being held this week can be found on the Beltane Facebook page, said Mr Spence.Activities include a quiz on June  and a couple of virtual discos.

title: face-masks-wear-one-properly-stop-glasses-steaming
story: A NEW law means that face coverings are now compulsory acrossEngland when using public transport.Some form of facial protection must be worn for commuters to be able to travel on public trains and buses as of today , with the law to be enforced by transport operators and British Transport police ldquo necessary.Travellers can be fined and refused travelthey do not comply with the law.Very young children, disabled people and those who have breathing dficulties are exempt from the rules, but all other public transport users must comply fromJune .At the time of publication - similar rules regarding face masks and public transport have not been implemented across Scotland, Walesand Northern Ireland.But which types of face coverings are acceptable, and how do you wear them properly How do I wear a face mask properly The UK Government has advised that scarves, or homemade cotton coverings, that cover the nose and mouth are fine to wear- so, too, arebought masks that are not the same as those used by the health service.Surgical masks should be kept for use by health professionals.Officials have said that people can make a face covering at home, but added it is key to ensure it covers your nose and mouth.Government guidancestates that a cloth face covering should cover your mouth and nose while allowing you to breathe comfortably. This can be as simple as a scarf or bandana that ties behind the head.Before putting it on, you should wash your hands or use hand sanitiser and do the same after removing it.Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth at all times and store any used face coverings in a plastic bag until you have an opportunity to wash them.Do not touch the front of the face covering, or the part of the face covering that has been in contact with your mouth and nose.Once removed, make sure you clean any surfaces the face covering has touched and wash the covering regularly. The covering can be washed with other laundry, using your normal detergent.When wearing a face covering, take care to tuck away any loose ends.How do I stop my glasses from steaming up If you wear glasses, wearing a face mask at the same time can cause the lenses to steam up, making it dficult to see properly.But the common problem has an easy solution, thanks to advice from doctors in the medical journal Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England.To prevent the issue, doctors advise washing your glasses with soapy water before putting the mask on, and rinsing them under warm water.Then, gently dry off the lenses with a clean towel or cloth before putting them back on.Washing the lenses with soapy water leaves behind a ldquothin surfactant film that reduces misting on the lenses, meaning they now shouldnrsquot steam up when a face mask is worn.Should face coverings be worn where The current government advice states that face coverings should be worn in enclosed spaces, which includes some shops and public transport.At the moment, people are not being told to wear them outdoors, while exercising, or in schools or offices.Several airlines, including easyJet and Ryanair, have introduced a requirement for passengers to wear face masks on board.However, the government believes that face masks should be reserved for people who need them to protect against risks in their workplace, such as health and care workers.

title: borders-priest-moving-rome-new-job
story: A BORDERS priest has accepted a high-ranking job in Rome.Nick Welsh, , has been based in Galashiels for the past two years.But he will soon be flying out to Italy after being picked for the role of vice-rector at the Scots College, where aspiring Scottish priests receive their training.Father Nick, originally from Stirling, told the Border he had ldquomixed emotions when he heard the news.He said: ldquoIrsquom quite excited, but Irsquoll have a bit of a heavy heart when I leave ndash I was just getting used to the Borders.Since , Father Nick has been administrator of the Parish of Our Lady  St Andrew, which has churches in Galashiels, Melrose and Selkirk.He said: ldquoI was really warmly welcomed here. Irsquom a bit of a city boy, but I was very much welcomed into a place I was very unfamiliar with.Asked what his favourite parts of the job have been, he highlighted working with local children, saying: ldquoIt was a really great thing to be involved with the schools here.His routine has seen him leading services in Galashiels , Melroseand Selkirk .But he has also visited the Borders General Hospital and people who are unable to leave home due to illness.Last week, however, he received a surprise phone call saying he had been selected for the Scots College job.ldquoI was a student there from -, so itrsquos a very familiar place but it was quite a surprise to me to be asked to go back, Father Nick said.ldquoIrsquove only been here for two years and I thought I would be here for a bit longer.ldquoOften you would be in a place for  years before you move on.Father Nick was happy to accept the new post, though, having enjoyed living in the Italian capital previously.ldquoI loved living in Rome so Irsquom quite excited about moving back, he said.ldquoI love being a priest and helping others to become a priest will be something Irsquoll be quite energised by.Father Nick, who intends to fly out in August, will be second-in-command and will take care of the administration of the college.He says he will also teach priests ldquohow to preach and give guidance on ldquopractical aspects of the job.The Scots College currently boasts three Borderers in its ranks, according to Father Nick ndash including former disc jockey Bobby Taylor from Galashiels.Josh Moir is also from Galashiels, while Martin Eckersley is from Jedburgh.

title: easyjet-restarts-flights-full-list-destinations-can-fly
story: Easyjet has restarted a small number of its flightsto a limited amountof destinations withstricter cleaning and safety measures for staff and passengers.Heres a round-up ofeverything you need to know.When did Easyjet restart flights Easyjet relaunched its flights from  airports across Europe for the first time on Monday, June , since they were halted at the end of March due to the coronavirus pandemic.The first flight from the UK took off on Monday morning from London Gatwick at am for Glasgow, which was the same flight path the airline first took when it launched in November .What destinations is Easyjet flying to Easyjet will be offering a reduced roster of destinations available for passengers - the plan is to be able to fly  per cent of its normal , routes in July, and  per cent in August.While there will be fewer flights on offer, travellers will have their pick of flights to domestic, city and beach destinations.These are all the destinations available from the Easyjet summer  flying programme:AlbaniaAustriaBelgiumBulgariaCroatiaCyprusCzech RepublicDenmarkEgyptEstoniaFranceGermanyGibraltarGreeceHungaryIcelandIsraelItalyKosovoMontenegroMoroccoNetherlandsPolandPortugalSerbiaSloveniaSpainSwedenSwitzerlandTurkeyCities around the UKThe airline confirmed that flights will resume from airports across the UK, including:London GatwickBristolBirminghamLiverpoolNewcastleEdinburghGlasgowInvernessBelfastWhat are the increased safety measures for staff and passengers Easyjet has introduced extra safety measures in order to keep staff and passengers safe during their flights.Additional cleaning and disinfection procedures for aircraft cabins will be in place, with every aircraft subject to a daily disinfection process.All passengers and crew will be required to wear masks at all times. The airline has also teamed up with a superhero illustrator to create comic book-inspired face masks for children.Artist Will Sliney is best known for his work on Marvel comics, like Spiderman and Star Wars.Aircrafts will be fully equipped with sanitary equipment - including masks, gloves and hand sanitiser -which will be available to customers and crew throughout the flight, where required.The aircraft are also fitted with ldquostate of the art filtration technology which ldquofilters . per cent of airborne contaminants in the cabin, including virus and bacteria, according to a statement from Easyjet.

title: lineker-backs-rashford-school-meals
story: Gary Lineker, the Labour Party and other prominent figures have joined footballer Marcus Rashford in calls for the Government to extend its free school meal voucher scheme through the summer holidays.The Manchester United and England star penned an open letter this week asking the Government to reverse its decision to cease the scheme ndash for which nearly . million children are eligible ndash outside of school term time.The -year-old has followed up with a column in The Times newspaper on Tuesday, addressing the meal voucher issue and the broader subject of childhood poverty.ldquoI donrsquot claim to have the education of an MP in parliament, but I do have a social education, Mr Rashford wrote.ldquoI am clued up on the dference a U-turn decision would make on the . million vulnerable children across the UK who are registered for free school meals because ten years ago I was one of them.While a Department for Education spokesman has said the national voucher scheme ldquowill not run during the summer holidays, Boris Johnsonrsquos official spokesman says the Prime Minister will respond to Mr Rashfordrsquos letter ldquoas soon as he can.The campaign received a further push on Monday night when Mr Lineker told BBC Newsnight he urged the Government to consider the struggles of impoverished families during the coronavirus crisis.ldquoObviously these are strange times. Kids wouldnrsquot ordinarily be fed during the summer holidays, I understand that. But yoursquove got to look at it and go lsquoThese are very, very dficult times for a lot of people and a lot of familiesrsquo, the former England striker and Match of the Day presenter said.ldquoThere are a lot of young people, young children, in this country that are going hungry. And in a country like ours, a country of quite substantial wealth, that seems to be largely unacceptable.ldquoHopefully the powers that be will listen. It seems strange that we have to be in a position where we are desperately arguing to try to get young people fed, and stop them being hungry.vw,vw,px, px"Gary Lineker has echoed Marcus Rashfordrsquos call for free school meal vouchers to continue over the summer, and has praised the -year-old for taking his stance Meanwhile, the Labour Party say they will today use an opposition day debate in Parliament to call on the Government to continue to directly fund the provision of free school meals over the holidays.Labour launched a Holidays Without Hunger campaign on Sunday.Shadow education secretary Rebecca Long Bailey will say: ldquoAny government that is willing to let the poorest children in the country go hungry needs to take a long hard look at its priorities.ldquoShamefully, children go hungry every year, but this summer will be especially dficult for many families as job losses and reduced incomes hit household budgets.ldquoIt would be deeply callous of the government not to take this small step to ease the financial pressure on households and ensure children can eat during the summer holidays.There are  postcodes in the Bolton South East contingency that have the level of child poverty at over % according to Child Poverty Action Group. % !! #maketheuturnmdash Marcus RashfordJune , Former Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw added his name to the cause, saying the Government ldquoshould be bending on this one and that Mr Rashford was ldquoabsolutely right to draw attention to this.ldquoI know lots of head teachers who are so worried about their children who are on free school meals, their poorest children, who have lost out the most during this crisis, Sir Michael told Newsnight.ldquoThose head teachers are going to bringing those children in over the summer break, theyrsquore going to be inviting their staff into school over the summer break to teach them, to make sure they donrsquot lose out any more.ldquoNowtheyrsquore going to be doing that, and those children are going to be coming into school over the summer break, to catch up, they need food.vw,vw,px, px"Rebecca Long Bailey will speak out on the issue in Parliament on Tuesday Kevin Courtney, joint general secretary of the National Education Union, the countryrsquos biggest teachersrsquo union, said the union ldquofully supports Mr Rashfordrsquos demand to provide free school meals over the summer.Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said: ldquoIf the Government is genuinely committed to social equity, it must extend the provision of free school meals to continue during the summer holidays.Mr Rashford, who has raised pound million to boost food distribution with the charity FareShare, has said he used food banks and received free meals during his underprivileged childhood in Manchester.Mr Lineker also praised Mr Rashford, saying: ldquoWhen you look at it, though, hersquos a  year old footballer. He shouldnrsquot be the one having to do this. But the fact that he is, is important. Itrsquos impressive. Hersquos a very fine young man, and hersquos a credit to his sport and his family.The voucher scheme provides pound worth of vouchers a week for each eligible child, which can be redeemed in a range of supermarkets.The Welsh Government has said free school meals will continue in Wales through the summer.The Department for Education spokesman also said thousands of children would also receive ldquoadditional support through our Holiday Activities and Food programme, which offers activities and free meals throughout the summer holidays..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Lineker backs Rashford over school meals

title: hollywood-bowl-reopen-centres-england-july-4
story: Hollywood Bowl plans to reopen centres in England from July , the company has announced.In accordance with current Government guidelines,  centres across the country will welcome back bowlers for the first time since lockdown began in March.Cleaning and social distancing measures will be introduced, including a reduction in the number of lanes, with customer guidance throughout the venues.Amusement machines and bar and diner seating will be appropriately spaced out and signs will remind customers to maintain a safe distance from others.There will be reduced customer capacity and groups will be restricted a maximum of six people, with bowlers asked to arrive slightly ahead of their booking time.Customers could be required to queue before entering the venue and checking in for their games. They will also be given the option of wearing disposable gloves and will be asked to wear their own footwear.Enhanced cleaning will take place throughout the day, including bowling balls, lane seating and touch screens.Staff members will undergo daily temperature checks and will be wearing personal protective equipment .Stephen Burns, chief executive at Hollywood Bowl Group, said: ldquoThe health and safety of our customers and team remains our priority.ldquoWhether itrsquos to bowl, enjoy the amusement areas, have a bite to eat or something to drink, we want to assure our customers that we are doing everything we can to create a safe and fun experience for families toto.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming them back through our doors very soon.Customers can make bookings in England on the Hollywood Bowl website, with slots available from July .Centres in Scotland and Wales are likely to remain closed until later in the month..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Hollywood Bowl to reopen centres in England from July

title: new-zealand-records-two-new-cases-coronavirus
story: New Zealand is no longer free from the new coronavirus after health officials say two women who flew from London to see a dying parent had tested positive.But before they were tested, the women had been given an exemption to leave quarantine on compassionate grounds and had travelled from Auckland to Wellington by car.Director-General of Health Ashley Bloomfield said that as part of their travel plan, the women had no contact with any people or any public facilities on their road trip.vw,vw,px, px"The country reported earlier this month it had eradicated the virus domestically Nevertheless, the new cases have sparked a round of testing in New Zealand for anybody who might have been close to the women.That includes passengers and staff on their flights, which arrived via Brisbane in Australia, other people at the Auckland hotel they initially stayed at in quarantine, and a family member they met in Wellington.The women remain in isolation in Wellington and have delayed the funeral of their parent until they have recovered.Until Tuesday, New Zealand had gone more than three weeks without any new cases and had declared that everybody who had contracted the virus had recovered, aside from the  people who died..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: New Zealand records two new cases of coronavirus

title: greggs-reopen-800-stores-thursday
story: Greggs has announced it plans to reopen around  stores to customers for takeaways from Thursday with the aim of welcoming sausage roll seekers to the remaining , sites by early July.Bosses unveiled the new-look stores, with floor markings, protective clothes for staff and screens at counters among several measures to protect against coronavirus spreading.There will also be a reduced menu to ensure social distancing in kitchens and workspaces.vw,vw,px, px"Greggs will reopen  stores on Thursday after initial trials. Greggs warned sales are likely to remain subdued as the chain copes with fewer customers allowed in stores at any one time, following a series of small-scale trials near its offices.As a result of the expected fall in sales, an unspecied proportion of staff ldquowill remain furloughed until sales levels begin ing to normal, the company said.The Newcastle-based business has taken a tentative approach to reopening, with management keen to avoid any rushes or overcrowding at sites following its three-month closure.Rivals KFC and McDonaldrsquos have seen long car queues for drive-thru services and non-essential retailers were greeted with hundreds of shoppers waiting to snap up a bargain, as stores were able to reopen their doors on Monday.Greggs had been allowed to stay open throughout the lockdown, offering takeaway and delivery services.But bosses declined, saying it felt remaining open would compromise the safety of its employees.Updating the stock market on Tuesday morning, the company added it remains cautious and warned sales may fall.It said: ldquoWe are not able to predict the impact of social distancing on our ability to trade or on customer demand.ldquoHowever, our capacity to operate will be restricted by size of shop and we must anticipate that sales may be lower than normal for some time.ldquoThis will require us to maintain a proportion of our colleagues on furlough, either fully or partially, until sales levels begin ing to normal.ldquoIn anticipation of lower sales, we have limited our initial product range to our best sellers and therefore a number of our manufacturing operational teams will remain furloughed until demand reaches a level that justies the addition of remaining product lines.vw,vw,px, px"Greggs is also reopening some drive-thrus. Longer term, the company added it has temporarily suspended its new shop opening plans, beyond those legally committed to, with just  new sites expected.Greggs has also spoken to landlords with a ldquoiety of proposals infor rent reductions and will switch to monthly payments from June, following a full quarterly rent payment in March.Chief executive Roger Whiteside said: ldquoLooking forward, although great uncertainty remains, we are excited to be resuming our service for many customers this week.ldquoWe are confident of our ability to adapt to market conditions in the short term while continuing to invest in the long-term growth of our business..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Greggs to reopen  stores on Thursday

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: county-rugby-club-given-1-000-boost
story: Dunbar RFC has been given the four-figure sum by Persimmon Homes Building Futures scheme.The initiative will see poundmillion given away across Britain to regional charities, groups, sports clubs and schools to improve local facilities and the delivery of vital community projects for people aged under .Dunbar Rugby Football Club is the first recipient of the recently launched initiative and supports more than  people under the age of .The club works closely with primary and secondary schools to encourage young people to play rugby in a safe and enjoyable environment.The club plan to use the funds to replace fencing that surrounds the main pitch at Hallhill Sports Centre.Building Futures aims to support community groups working with under-s across three categories ndash education and arts, health and sport.In addition to hundreds of local donations of pound,,  initiatives will go on to compete for top prizes of pound, through a national online public vote.Laura Still, sales and marketing director for Persimmon Homes East Scotland, said: ldquoWe are proud to support Dunbar Rugby Football Club, who offer a valuable opportunity for young people to develop new skills and boost confidence.ldquoWith so many chances to win vital funding for their projects, we urge charities, schools and sports clubs to apply online before May .

title: scottish-open-take-place-renaissance-club-october
story: The impact of the coronavirus saw the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open postponed last month.However, the European Tour has now confirmed that the tournament, which will be played at The Renaissance Club, near Archerfield, will take place from October -.Keith Pelley, European Tour Chief Executive, said: ldquoSince the suspension of our  season in early March, we have taken a measured approach in reassessing our schedule, informed every step of the way by our medical advisers and government guidance.ldquoWe have consistently said that safety is our absolute priority and that is why today we are announcing our resumption in two monthsrsquo time supported by a comprehensive health strategy which has been led by our medical team.ldquoWithout question we have had to think dferently about the remainder of our  season which is reflected in todayrsquos announcement.ldquoAs golfrsquos global Tour, ersity is ordinarily one of our biggest strengths, but in this instance it has become one of our biggest challenges.ldquoInitially, therefore, based on the expert guidance we received, playing in clusters, in one territory, is the best option in terms of testing, travel and accommodation.It is the second year in a row that the competition has been played at the East Lothian course.Last yearrsquos event was won by Bernd Wiesberger after a play-off with Benjamin Hebert.Among those hoping to line up at the tournament is North Berwicks Grant Forrest.The -year-old, who finished tied for rd at least years event, said: "It is great it is going ahead."Obviously, so much uncertainty in the last few months and the guys on the European Tour have been working really hard to put something together for us."I am glad they have got it on the schedule and I hope the weather is alright in October ndash who knows what it could be like "There was a point where I thought it would almost be a year off, which would have been a real shame."They have done really well to give us so many events already and with the hope they could add a few more."Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was pleased to hear the event had been rescheduled.He said: ldquoI very much look forward to welcoming world class golfers back to East Lothian for this fantastic tournament."We will of course work closely with the European Tour and in accordance with guidance on the detail of how the tournament can be run safely."It is an encouraging development and signals that Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast will be back open for business this year albeit with some restrictions still in place.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, was similarly pleased to see the event rescheduled but stressed it remained to be seen how the tournament would look in terms of a crowd.He said: "I think it is great news not only for Scottish golf itself but for tourism in general."Hopefully, by then, we will be able to have crowds as well but I am really not sure what the rules on that are going to be yet ndash whether it is crowds or played behind closed doors, it would be a bit oddit was behind closed doors."In general, we will have to wait and see what the rules are about crowds."That is what produces the benefit in the short-term to the local economy."Mr Findlay highlighted that the tourism sector had taken "a huge hit" during the coronavirus crisis and many businesses would have to survive until next year before tourism started to resume in the traditional way.Currently, the Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open is pencilled in for August - at the same venue.Last yearrsquos event was won by Mi Jung Hur.

title: water-lovers-paradise-look-new-plans
story: A water park, with the opportunity to swim and kayak, is part of the proposals revealed by the local authority with a series of images also unveiled.The proposed ClimatEvolution Zone would cover the under-construction town of Blindwells and surroundingcommunities stretching from Prestonpans to Longniddry and inland to Tranent and Macmerry.East Lothian Council is petitioning the Scottish Government to extend the National Development status given to the former Cockenzie Power Station site in its National Planning Frameworkdocument to a wider area in its planned revised framework which is under review.This could pave the way for the creation of the ClimatEvolution Zone which could transform the area over the next  years through innovative approaches to development.A public consultation on the vision has been launched by the council and breaks the plans down into dferent themes from environment to travel.It asks people to give their views on its approach to a wide range of issues including access and movement the water environment culture, heritage and leisure greenspace and bioersity strong communities and regeneration and enterprise.However, the vision has already come under fire from Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council which branded it ldquocomplex and unclear.The community council warned that the launch of a new vision for the area three years after the local authority produced its Cockenzie Masterplan document ndash which it has never adopted ndash would leave the public with no confidence in the planning system.East Lothian Council paid consultants to produce the Cockenzie Masterplan for the former Cockenzie Power Station site, which it owns, after a series of public consultations in  but the report remains an informal ldquovisionary document.Now the former power station site could be merged into the new ClimatEvolution Zone with no reference to the original masterplan.Bryan Hickman, community council chairman, said: ldquoThe community council are very concerned by the documents recently published by the council."We understood that the changes required for NPF related to the former power station site."The y report now extends to Tranent, Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton, Longniddry and Blindwells as well as the power station site."Whilst some of the objectives are to be welcomed, the overall content is complex and unclear and includes such a large area as to be unmanageable in its detail.ldquoThe existing communities have been consulted on the power station site and the result was a masterplan commissioned by the council but not adopted by them."We have submitted this masterplan to be included in NPF."A number of consultations have taken place in our area and they have come to nothing."The feeling is the residents have lost confidence in the system.Neighbouring Prestonpans Community Council also raised concerns about the consultation.Brian Weddell, chairman, questioned whether the proposed train station in the new plan would ever happen, saying: ldquoThere has been no meaningful consultation with local communities who all have concerns about the impact of this development on their communities.The new consultation is based around a study, drawn up in partnership with East Lothian Council, the Scottish Government, The Lothian Drainage Partnership, SEPA, Scottish Water and Scottish Natural Heritage.It considers how the council can take the opportunity of creating a new town at Blindwells and harness the latest technologies to reduce the arearsquos carbon footprint.Among the ideas up for discussion is using groundwater at Blindwells to create waterways and using natural geothermic energy to heat the outdoor water features.Douglas Proudfoot, project leader, said the idea behind the new water features was to avoid putting pipes underground to remove groundwater and utilise it instead as the new town of Blindwells develops on the former opencast coal site of the same name between Longniddry and Tranent.The first houses are due to be built later this year.He said: ldquoWe have a unique opportunity here with a blank canvas for a new town at a time when climate change is central to policies."I also think the Covid- pandemic has driven forward the idea that people can work from home and find alternative ways to work with the support of digital technology.Central to the vision is alternative ways to travel with an emphasis on walkways and cycle routes.A new train station at a central hub within an area the council has dubbed Greater Blindwells will provide additional access to public transport.To the north of the central hub between Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry there are proposals for a water park or outdoor leisure area with the potential to create a lido with space for kayaking and other water sports.At the former Cockenzie Power Station site, less than half-a-mile away, a new centre of excellence is proposed described as a training school and ldquoexemplar developmentin modular manufacture and construction.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the ambitious strategy.He said: ldquoThe Cockenzie and Blindwells sites are adjacent to one another and it has always been inevitable that their development will be closely linked, so it makes sense to seek to extend National Development status to Blindwells.ldquoThe whole area offers unique potential to transform these former industrial sites into places where people can live and work in a sustainable way.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, also welcomed the project which will lsquointeractrsquo with neighbouring communities.He said: ldquoThe area is a far wider community and cannot be seen in isolation.The inclusion of adjacent communities is therefore essential.Councillor Norman Hampshire stressed the proposals are not a lsquofinalised masterplanrsquo but rather a ldquohigh level document which sets out an ambitious vision for the area over the coming  years.He said: ldquoItrsquos an exciting opportunity to ensure that one of the key areas of East Lothian, is developed in an innovative way."Itrsquos not all about whatrsquos new, though."We are looking at enhancing the existing local environment and making the most of the arearsquos unique history as well as its mining and agricultural heritage and the site of the Battle of Prestonpans.The council launched its eightweek consultation on its online hub on Monday.The Scottish Government is revising its National Development Planning Framework which gives an overview of what it wants to see develop on key sites across Scotland.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoWe are grateful for the many views and ideas received in response to early engagement on National Planning Framework  .Our analysis of the responses is underway and will continue over the summer, and we expect to publish an update in the autumn.The council consultation can be found at eastlothianconsultations

title: postal-workers-gather-applaud-edington-staff
story: Residents on St Baldredrsquos Road cheered the Royal Mail workers and the Edington nurses, who waved from the hospital doorway.Royal Mail delivery office manager Paul Howson said: ldquoThese nurses are the backbone of our country and are putting their own lives in jeopardy every day going to work we cannot thank them enough.The local posties are known for going that extra mile to help others.A video posted on Facebook two weeks ago showed their vans pulling up to deliver a bundle of birthday presents to Mr Howsonrsquos daughter Keira, aged , at home during lockdown.Mr Howson said: ldquoShe messaged me that night to say it was the best birthday ever. Irsquom not going to lie, I was a bit emotional myself ndash I had to sneak away round the corner!ldquoIt just shows how much of a team they [the postal workers] are.ldquoWhen I mentioned doing it [delivering the presents to Keira], one of them ed from Gullane to help, one came back from Athelstaneford, just to do that, then went back out to finish their delivery.ldquoThey have been so flexible since the start of the pandemic ndash theyrsquove had to make all sorts of changes.ldquoPeople are doing afternoon shts, who never normally would people are coming in at am who would never normally start till half seven, to adhere to social distancing.ldquoI feel the whole community has come together.ldquoThe generosity and behaviour of everyone in the town towards the postal workers right now is amazing.ldquoSome of us are getting gts, all the supportive signs in peoplersquos windows, itrsquos great.The North Berwick postal staff have also donated three bags of soap, toothpaste and other toiletries to the Edington.

title: students-tour-preston-lodge-high-school-homes
story: Pupils are due toto Preston Lodge High School on August , following the summer holidays and coronavirus lockdown.Now, a short video has been created for those students leaving P behind and moving up to secondary school.The video, included in the schoolrsquos electronic newsletter PLus, allows people to look behind the doors of the Prestonpans secondary school.The newsletter notes: ldquoAs part of the launch of our P transition programme, we have provided all P students and their families with a virtual tour of our school building.ldquoMany thanks to Sarah Lusk [support for learning] for the great job that she has done.ldquoWe thought that some of our older PLers might enjoy revisiting the school that we are all missing!Watching the video allows potential pupils the chance to get their bearings and find dferent departments.Jonny Else, depute headteacher at the secondary school, told the Courier: ldquoIt is part of the transition programme because the pupils cannot physically be in the building just now.ldquoWe are trying to get them more comfortable about the surroundings and a lot of the feedback we have had from P pupils is they want to know where everything is in the school.A further video highlighting dferent departments is also being created.Mr Else added: ldquoThe building is probably more than double the size what they are used to and there are so many dferent rooms and departments.ldquoThe video is to make them feel as relaxed as they can in this dficult time.He added it was not just for future pupils at the school. Preston Lodge alumni can also refamiliarise themselves with their former secondary school.To view the video, go to www.edubuzz.org prestonlodge    p_transition_

title: musselburgh-sea-cadet-named-one-9-000-ordinary-heroes
story: In addition to being the officer-in-charge at Musselburgh Sea Cadets, Chris Gay, , is a busy ambulance control officer with the Scottish Ambulance Service.He said: ldquoI deal directly with Covid- patients as well as medical professionals across Scotland and my job is make sure the patients get the care they need as quickly as possible.ldquoI love being part of the service.ldquoEvery call is dferent and every call is a person needing help. I love to make sure they receive the first step along the way to getting the right patient care.He added: ldquoItrsquos helped my people skills which has also helped me within sea cadets.ldquoI was quite quiet when I started which is unusual for sea cadets.ldquoWhen you work with so many people, it brings you out of yourself and itrsquos definitely taken me out of my comfort zone.Eighty-five per cent of sea cadet activities at unit level are taking place lsquovirtuallyrsquo despite the loss of hugely popular inshore and offshore boating programmes, competitions and the international exchange programme.Sea Cadets remains an important part of many young peoplersquos lives with nearly , cadets nationwide. During lockdown, the impact of its volunteers on their lives hasnrsquot stopped, with a recent survey showing wide satisfaction with the lsquovirtualrsquo sea cadetsrsquo programme.Captain Phil Russell, RN, Captain of Sea Cadets, said Chris was one of the ldquoordinary heroes across the UK who was helping Sea Cadets offer a dferent kind of adventure to young people.As officer-in-charge he is holding weekly Zoom sessions and Google Classrooms to train sea cadets in a series of skills such as in first aid, cooking and engineering.Captain Russell said: ldquoSea Cadets are proud of our strong links with the Royal Navy but volunteers join us from all walks of le and no previous nautical experience is needed.ldquoWhen you start volunteering with us you can be assured of a warm welcome and an amazing experience as part of the sea cadet family.Musselburgh Sea Cadets also recently raised funds through crowdfunding to buy treats such as sweets, chocolates and small gts for hard-working frontline health care workers during the Covid- crisis.A major pound, refurbishment of TS Indefatigable, their South Street base, had also just got underway when the Covid- lockdown struck.Potential volunteers who want to join Sea Cadets can find their local unit by going to the website at www.sea-cadets.orgVolunteersrsquo Week takes place June - every year.Itrsquos a chance to celebrate and say thank you for the contribution millions of volunteers make across the UK.

title: kids-create-chain-key-workers-tesco-superstore
story: They were asked to create a window display for the store by its community champion, Jane Shepherd, and were rewarded with some treats.The hub, based at Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, provides learning and childcare. Those who attend include the children of key workers and others with severe and complex additional support needs.Scarlett Palmer, depute head teacher at Pinkie St Peterrsquos, said: ldquoThe children, along with the staff, in their hub groups decided to create a chain of key workers with a rainbow shining over them.ldquoThe children decided which key workers should be represented and worked in small teams to design and decorate them based on their version of what the unorms should look like.ldquoThey had lots of fun making them and were rewarded with ice pops from Tesco, which were lovely on a warm day.ldquoThe display looks great in Tesco and Irsquom sure is bringing a little joy to customers as they queue outside.

title: schoolchildren-share-self-help-guides-coping-lockdown
story: They were tasked with producing, from home, advice on how to relax, and how to deal with boredom and being at home for such a long time.The youngsters in P also shared fun and interesting activities theyrsquod enjoyed during the lockdown.Teacher Stefan Thomson said: ldquoThis was part of their weekly learning grid, which contains learning tasks from a iety of dferent curricular areas.ldquoIrsquove been absolutely astounded with the resilience pupils have shown during this time.He added: ldquoThis task was intended to be a fun way to share coping strategies among pupils.ldquoHowever, after reading their amazing suggestions I realised how useful these could be for everyone finding it hard to cope.The children suggested activities such as yoga and meditation, as well as stressing the need for healthy eating.

title: community-effort-sees-well-7-000-meals-delivered-residents
story: And such is their prowess, they are now closing in on , meals!The ,th meal was handed over on May  to -year-old Margaret Mack, of Port Setonrsquos Thomson Crescent the servicersquos oldest customer, by the resilience teamrsquos youngest volunteer, Imogen Woods, , who regularly delivers Margaretrsquos meals.During lockdown, staff and volunteers at the Port Seton Centre have been producing and delivering hot meals and food packages to vulnerable residents and those most in need.They have been working with Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, who have been leading the local resilience effort.The centre is also supporting the work of the local school hub by providing children who would usually receive free school meals with breakfast and lunch packs.Bryan Hickman, chairman of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, said: ldquoI didnrsquot expect us to produce that many.ldquoItrsquos been going on as things continue, and helping a iety of people such as those shielding. . . we donrsquot know how long these people are going to be kept in.Donations of food have come from local residents, groups and businesses, as well as East Lothian Council and FareShare.The FareShare hub was set up last month, and sees surplus food from supermarkets donated to the centre.A new fridge and freezer was also delivered to the centre to store any fresh or frozen food that was delivered. Emma Brown, connected communities manager for the Preston Seton Gosford area, said: ldquoThe Port Seton Centre is delighted to be an active partner in the Cockenzie and Port Seton resilience team, providing vital support to vulnerable people during Covid-.ldquoWe are now far past the , meal delivery ndash and actually closer to , ndash and it shows how working together can make such a dference to community response.ldquoIt has been great to partner the community council, connected communities Preston Seton Gosfordstaff team, childrenrsquos hub, our vital volunteers and other members of the PSG Area Partnership to provide a local response.

title: letter-week-the-worst-time-us-all-many-years
story: It is all rightyou have a garden but,not, being confined to the house may be very nerve-wrackingyou have children to entertain.And what about elderly people who are on their own, what do they do I am alone, I donrsquot have family, so I depend on home care people coming in daily to help me cope from day to day. Unfortunately, I had major heart surgery in November last year and I have been mainly housebound in all that time, and I look forward to be able to get out for a wee while, as being in for thisof time has become very depressing.People are going out and about talking to each other and visiting their relatives but not everyone is following the rules, but people will do what they want.I would love to get out and about but I need someone to take me in a wheelchair but I donrsquot know who or when this will happen.Good luck to everyone.Carol McKayHaddington

title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour.
